thread.title: Bruce Billson rebuffs criticism of small biz unfair contracts bill
thread.title_full: Bruce Billson rebuffs criticism of small biz unfair contracts bill | afr.com

author: Ben Potter
title: Bruce Billson rebuffs criticism of small biz unfair contracts bill
text:
Unfair take-it-or-leave-it contracts place an unfair burden on small business, minister Bruce Billson says Virginia Star by Ben Potter Small Business Minister Bruce Billson rejected criticism that a $100,000 limit on the government's unfair contracts bill would undermine an election promise to protect small business.
Mr Billson said the bill was a "proven and substantial" measure to prevent "take-it-or-leave-it" standard form contracts form undermining the confidence of small business "to invest and grow".
He was responding to criticism of the Treasury Legislation Amendment (Small Business and Unfair Contract Terms) Bill 2015 from Ken Phillips, executive director of contractor lobby Independent Contractors Australia.
Mr Phillips said last week the organisation - originally one of the main backers of the bill - would now oppose it because it includes a $100,000 cap on protected contracts of less than a year's duration and $250,000 for contracts of more than a year.
He said the caps emasculated the bill and accused the government of breaking an election promise to protect small business from unfair standard contracts imposed by big business and government agencies in an email to ICA members.
But Mr Billson said the government couldn't be a "contract nanny" and small business people bore the primary duty to do proper due diligence on their contracts.
The government had had had to confine the bill to "consumer-like" standard-form contracts, he said.
"We have calibrated it to catch day-to-day take-it-or-leave-it contracts that small businesses have foisted on them that may include unfair contract terms that have no place in an economy that seeks to encourage all sorts of enterprises big and small."
 Unfair contract terms under scrutiny include terms under which the larger party reserves the right to unilaterally alter the terms or which automatically extend a three year contract for another three years unless the smaller party opts within a narrow window not to extend.
Based on a 2014 survey, Mr Billson said the legislation would enable the government to "strike out" objectionable clauses in 80 per cent of small business contracts.
But in its submission to the Senate economics legislation committee, the ICA said the caps would enable large corporations and government agencies to use the legal system to wriggle out of the protection.
Mr Phillips says the caps are deceptively low and would exclude many contracts entered into by self-employed accountants, lawyers, engineers, architects, builders, IT professionals, small retailers and family farmers.
Owner-drivers of trucks and other contractors would lose the shield because they have to include the cost of their expensive rigs, tools and plant.
